dt: {bc}a canal in a female mammal that leads from the uterus to the external orifice of the genital canal
{bc}a canal that is similar in function or location to the vagina and occurs in various animals other than mammals

et: borrowed from New Latin, going back to Latin {it}vāgīna{/it} "scabbard, sheath," of uncertain origin

Latin {it}vāgīna{/it} as an anatomical term does not appear to be earlier than the sixteenth century, though Roman use of the word as a sexual metaphor is as old as Plautus's comedy {it}Pseudolus{/it} ({ldquo}… quom tu ibas simul, conveniebatne in vaginam tuum machaera militis?{rdquo} - {ldquo}… when you were going with him, did the soldier's sword fit in your scabbard?{rdquo}). Latin {it}vāgīna{/it} has been compared with Lithuanian {it}vóžti{/it} {ldquo}to close with a lid or cover, shut{rdquo} (from Indo-European {it}*u̯eh{inf}2{/inf}ǵ-{/it}?), though a link is doubtful given the vague sense connection and lack of other comparanda. According to Ernout and Meillet ({it}Dictionnaire étymologique de la langue latine: histoire des mots,{/it} fourth edition, 1959), {ldquo}undoubtedly a borrowed technical term{rdquo} ({ldquo}terme technique sans doute emprunté{rdquo}).
shortdef: a canal in a female mammal that leads from the uterus to the external orifice of the genital canal
a canal that is similar in function or location to the vagina and occurs in various animals other than mammals
